reviewText: A manipulative girl and a spine-less man. She should have been used as a prototype for some major attack vehicle (the attitude, not the size) and he would have done well as a bathroom towel - soft and pliable and one can fold it any way one wants. Terribly afraid of dark stains, though. She decides first that she wants his bed (without him in it) and then him (with the bed). He does not decide anything.I suppose one of the main reasons why Olivier became such a fantastic Shakespear actor was that he understood that otherwise he would have had to play in more stupid movies like that one. That was a very wise decision.
summary: ..and oldie does not mean goldie every time.

reviewText: I purchased this movie because I have a copy in VHS of many moons ago.  That technology is dieing out.  I love B&W movies, so when this became available, I went for it.  I love to see Laurence Olivier act anyway.  Back in the day, he was handsome.  In the movies that I have of him, his character carries a certain act about it.  Merle Oberon is another actress that I love to see playing.  They were meant to be in this movie.

reviewText: First comments are specific to Diamond Entertainment's VHS of THE DIVORCE OF LADY X. Front cover is brown and orange, with Merle Oberon in PJs.Tape quality is POOR.Recorded in ELP mode, the image is blurry with bleeding colors. Tracking is irregular. HiFi audio blinks in and out and the linear backup sound track is bassy and murky. Overall, this is almost bootleg in quality..On the movie:It's a corny screwball comedy of few laughs. Barrister Olivier's hotel room is invaded by blueblooded Oberon when a heavy nighttime fog shuts down London's streets. She pushes Olivier out of his bed (he has to sleep on the floor on a mattress), and even appropriates the sap's extra set of pajamas.For all Oberon's cheek and demands, Olivier falls for her. Now this single upperclass woman lets the divorce lawyer wrongly conclude that their innocent night together has ended a non-existent marriage, and that the man who's come to him for help in severing ties with his wife is actually her own husband.I found the whole thing uncharming. My two star rating is for BOTH film content and manufacturing..Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating.(6.8) The Divorce of Lady X (UK-1938) - Merle Oberon/Laurence Olivier/Binnie Barnes/Ralph Richardson/Morton Selten/J.H. Roberts/Gertrude Musgrove/Gus McNaughton/H.B. Hallan (uncredited: Michael Rennie)
summary: "The trouble with me is that I'm weak. A charming young girl like you can put anything over on me in five minutes."

reviewText: I have lent this film to so many people who have never heard of it and they always love it!! I agree with a previous reviewer that it should be better known. I have a copy on video but now that I see it here in DVD I have ordered it. Sir Lawrence Olivier is so handsome and perfect in his role .... I especially savor Sir Ralph Richardson ...he is unbeatable and extremely funny in that inimitable British way...Being both an Anglophile and an enthusiast of the '30's and '40's, I found this picture to be one to which I always return for its wit, humour and presentation of '30's England.  It is a delightful, tasteful, reluctantly-romantic comedy /comedy of manners. A nice counterpoint to the vulgarity: (profanity, exploitation) which prevails in "modern" pictures. Highly recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The screwball comedy was a staple of the 1930s, and The Divorce of Lady X is a thoroughly enjoyable British entry into the movie genre. Here we have the young, Pre-"Wuthering Heights" Merle Oberon and Laurence Olivier as the mischievous Leslie Steele and misogynist, fussy barrister Everard Logan, respectively. Stuck at a London hotel during a fog, the guests of a fancy dress party--who included Oberon--are forced to take refuge in the hotel. Most rooms have been occupied by paying guests, and many are placed in the public rooms for the night, but the resourceful Leslie Steele fast-talks her way into Everard Logan's hotel room, overwhelming and bewildering the sleepy barrister. What follows after this night is a case of mistaken identities of comic proportion for Everard is convinced the woman who shared his room is the adulterous wife of a client who desires to divorce her, and that HE is the woman's lover! But he loves her, though he cannot prosecute himself for adultery! Needless to say, all ends well. A funny, cute and witty romantic comedy unlike those of today, The Divorce of Lady X is a hidden gem.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One doesn't immediately associate Laurence Olivier and Merle Oberon with screwball comedy. And, when you think of these two pairing up cinematically, you'd sooner arrive at WUTHERING HEIGHTS than THE DIVORCE OF LADY X. Except that THE DIVORCE OF LADY X, coming out in 1938, happens to be one of them sparkling romantic comedies, and suffused with wonderfully daft elements. For those who'd only ever seen Olivier and Oberon in dramatic roles, this movie demonstrates that, on occasion, they did do away with the stuffy.The plot? When an impenetrable fog rolls into Londontown and conspires to strand the attendants of a charity dress ball at the posh Royal Park Hotel, picture then the mad scramble for the few remaining suites. In Room #317, young and misogynistic barrister Everard Logan (Olivier) is inveigled by management to share his quarters. But, cross and "quite wild with fatigue" after arduous days of travel, Logan refuses to accomodate the marooned revelers.But here's Merle Oberon's mysterious character whom Logan will soon call "Lady X." And the Lady X, young and lovely and adventurous, will not take no for an answer. The next half hour or so treats us to an entertaining battle of the sexes as Logan and Lady X wage a war of wits, with Logan's modest suite as the sweet prize.Cut now to the following day and we eye Everard Logan, now deeply smitten with his stunning adversary. Except that the Lady X had just snuck away, leaving our man bereft of heart's desire and a pair of colorful pajamas (getcher mind out the gutter, as nothing happened). Reporting to his office, Logan is met by a new client, the cuckolded Lord Meer (Ralph Richardson), who promptly accuses his wife of unfaithfulness. As the divorce-minded Lord Meer recounts his suspicions, Logan comes to believe that Lady Meer - her track record: four marriages in five years, thrice divorced - is in fact his very own Lady X. What follows is a spate of colossal misunderstandings, mistaken identities, and comedic complications, with the elegant Laurence Olivier looking harried and befuddled thru it all.For triviaheads of early motion picture, THE DIVORCE OF LADY X is a frothier remake of the 1933 film COUNSEL'S OPINION. Shot in early Technicolor and lavishly produced by Alexander Korda (who had a little sumthin' sumthin' going on with the lead actress), THE DIVORCE OF LADY X is an utter delight. It showcases a superb - and startlingly comic - onscreen team in Olivier and Oberon. It features terrific support from Ralph Richardson and Binnie Barnes (as the been-around-the-block Lady Claire Meer). I love them Brit performers, brother. These are the sort of actors that can elevate an already wicked clever script. I love listening to them speak. I eat up the cadance and the mellifluous tones. If there were a nit to pick, it's that I wished there were more contentious scenes between Lady X's grandfather (Morton Selten) and his smart-alecky butler (H.B. Hallam). It's almost as much fun as watching the mischievous Lady X take her pompous barrister down a peg or three.As one reviewer already mentioned, do be aware that this DVD's distributing company ("Hollywood Select") is pretty cheeky with its display of its name on the screen's lower right for the entirety of the film. It's especially prominent when the scenes are set in dim lighting. I eventually paid it no mind. But can you?
summary: "But then I didn't like you in your office. I much preferred you in your bedroom."

But as you know the scandal is the half of the sin, and although it happened nothing, he is branded as "the other man" with laughable and unpredictable consequences that will make you love this film as I did it.A must-see.

reviewText: When a thick London fog prevents guests at a fancy dress ball from leaving the hotel, a young woman (Merle Oberon) is forced to spend the night with a young attorney (Laurence Olivier) in his hotel suite. They find themselves attracted to each other but in a case of mistaken identities, he mistakes her for the four time married wife of a client (Ralph Richardson). She plays along with his erroneous conclusions. This bright Technicolored attempt at screwball comedy looks like it was filmed inside a candy box. It goes into overdrive at being bubbly and witty and it occasionally succeeds but one can see the wheels spinning and the actors trying too hard. Olivier, looking quite handsome, still hadn't learned to relax in front of the camera yet (he credits William Wyler for teaching him to act on film the following year in WUTHERING HEIGHTS) and Merle Oberon was never very good at a light touch. Oscar winning Harry Stradling (MY FAIR LADY) did the lensing and if you didn't see his name in the credits, you'd never guess the innocuous score was by Miklos Rozsa. Directed by Tim Whelan (THIEF OF BAGDAD). With Binnie Barnes and Morton Selten.The region 2 Network DVD gives a vivid Technicolor transfer but a bit on the soft side.Comment
Title: N/A
